fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as \mathbf {Set} functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
By combining the work of Ahman and Uustalu on distributive laws for directed containers and our work, it is also easy enough to characterise mixed distributive laws.
I am a PhD student at Royal Holloway, University of London researching programming language semantics via cyclic proof theory, type theory, and category theory.
\mu HOL^{ex} is a logic and cyclic proof system that I've been developing for part of my PhD project with my supervisor Reuben Rowe.

The goal is to develop a proof system for higher-order logic with fixed-point operators, that allows for induction and coinduction by adding fixed-point "unfolding" rules, and allowing proofs to be cyclic.

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as \mathbf {Set} functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
By combining the work of Ahman and Uustalu on distributive laws for directed containers and our work, it is also easy enough to characterise mixed distributive laws.
This website uses the Forester tool developed by Jon Sterling. See Jon's website for tutorials/information about the tool.
It is a fantastic way to organise notes and I've been enjoying it a lot! There is even a VSCode plugin.
This can be extended to a fully faithful functor from the category of monad containers and monad container maps to the category of \mathbf {Set}-monads and monad maps. [uustalu2017]

Let (S \triangleright P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleright Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers. A distributive law of S \triangleright P over T \triangleright Q is given by the data: \begin {align*} &u_1 : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to T) \to T \\ &u_2 : \prod _{s : S} \prod _{f : P\ s \to T} Q\ (u_1\ s\ f) \to S \\ &v_1 : \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to T\}} \prod _{q : Q\ (u_1\ s\ f)} P\ (u_2\ s\ f\ q) \to P\ s \\ &v_2 : \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to T\}} \prod _{q : Q\ (u_1\ s\ f)} \prod _{p : P\ (u_2\ s\ f\ q)} Q\ (f\ (v_1\ q\ p)) \\ \end {align*} where the following equalities hold: \begin {align*} u\ \iota ^S\ (\lambda \_ . t) &= (t , \lambda \_ . \iota ^S)\\ u\ s\ (\lambda \_. \iota ^T) &= (\iota ^T , \lambda \_. s)\\ v\ \{\iota ^S\}\ \{\lambda \_. t\} &= \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle \\ v\ \{s\}\ \{\lambda \_. \iota ^T\} &= \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle \\ \\ u_1\ (\sigma ^S\ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}^S) &= u_1\ s\ (u_1 \circ \langle f , g \rangle )\\ u_2\ (\sigma ^S\ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}^S)\ q &= \sigma ^S\ (u_2\ s\ (u_1 \circ \langle f , g \rangle )\ q)\ (\lambda p . u_2\ (f\ (v_1\ q\ p))\ (g\ (v_1\ q\ p))\ (v_2\ q\ p))\\ \text {pr}^S_1\ (v_1\ q\ p) &= v_1\ q\ (\text {pr}^S_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}^S_2\ (v_1\ q\ p) &= v_1\ (v_2\ q\ (\text {pr}^S_1\ p))\ (\text {pr}^S_2\ p)\\ v_2\ q\ p &= v_2\ (v_2\ q\ (\text {pr}^S_1\ p))\ (\text {pr}^S_2\ p)\\ \\ u_1\ s\ (\sigma ^T \circ \langle f , g \rangle ) &= \sigma ^T\ (u_1\ s\ f)\ (\lambda q . u_1\ (u_2\ s\ f\ q)\ (\lambda p . g\ (v_1\ q\ p)\ (v_2\ q\ p)))\\ u_2\ s\ (\sigma ^T \circ \langle f , g \rangle )\ q &= u_2\ (u_2\ s\ f\ (\text {pr}^T_1\ q))\ (\lambda p . g\ (v_1\ q\ p)\ (v_2\ q\ p))\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\\ v_1\ (\text {pr}^T_1\ q)\ (v_1\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\ p) &= v_1\ q\ p\\ v_2\ (\text {pr}^T_1\ q)\ (v_1\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\ p) &= \text {pr}^T_1\ (v_2\ q\ p)\\ v_2\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\ p &= \text {pr}^T_2\ (v_2\ q\ p) \end {align*} We use the notation \langle f , g \rangle := \lambda x . (f\ x , g\ x), with some implicit use of currying and uncurrying where this shorthand is utilised.
u is defined as \langle u_1 , u_2 \rangle and v is defined as \langle v_1 , v_2 \rangle .
Monad container distributive laws allow you to define a notion of composition for monad containers.
